documentType: last will and testament with codicils
summary: This document is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, dated December 11, 2001, and five subsequent codicils (2003-2007). It details the appointment and changes to executors, the bequest of his estate to a trust, and grants extensive powers to the executors. The document is significant for identifying key individuals Epstein designated to manage his estate.

connections.description: Epstein appointed Schantz as a trustee of his 2001 trust and as an original executor of his will, indicating a trusted financial/legal relationship.
Epstein appointed Jarecki as an executor of his will in 2003, indicating a trusted relationship to manage his estate.
Epstein appointed Cayne as an executor of his will in 2003, indicating a trusted relationship to manage his estate.
Epstein added Newman as an executor in 2004; Newman is identified as an attorney (Esq.).
Epstein designated Indyke as a successor executor in 2004, indicating a trusted legal/fiduciary role.
Both were appointed as co-executors of Epstein's will in the same codicil.
Indyke replaced Hoffman as the designated successor executor in the third codicil.

events.title: Execution of Fifth Codicil
events.description: Epstein executed the fifth codicil, increasing executor compensation to $500,000 each.

locations: Little St. James Island, United States Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Jeffrey E. Epstein's will bequeaths all his property to 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust One,' a trust he created on November 8, 2001.
The executors of the will were changed multiple times between 2001 and 2007, ultimately settling on Henry Jarecki, James Cayne, and Lawrence Newman, with Darren K. Indyke as successor.
Executor compensation was increased from $100,000 in the original will to $250,000 in 2004, and finally to $500,000 in 2007.
The will includes a 'no-contest' clause, disinheriting any beneficiary who challenges the will or the trust.
The executors are granted extremely broad and discretionary powers over the estate's assets, including the authority to operate without court supervision or bond.
